### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

  |

  |                ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

  |

  |                                 ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);

   |
19 |     var o2 := optimize(e2);
   |                            ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) = e.

   |
29 |   // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) = e.
   |                                                               ^

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // so it is vacuously optimal.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call

   |
30 |   // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // since e is not Add(_, Const(0)) or Add(Const(0), _), by the definition

   |
30 |   // since e is not Add(_, Const(0)) or Add(Const(0), _), by the definition
   |                                                                            ^

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // so optimal(optimize(e)) holds iff optimal(e) holds.

   |
30 |   // so optimal(optimize(e)) holds iff optimal(e) holds.
   |                                                         ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is obvious that optimal(e) => optimal(optimize(e)) since e and optimize(e) are the same.

   |
30 |   // it is obvious that optimal(e) => optimal(optimize(e)) since e and optimize(e) are the same.
   |                                                                                                 ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call
  // in the match statement for optimize will not be reached.

   |
31 |   // in the match statement for optimize will not be reached.
   |                                                              ^

ex.dfy(31,61): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None

Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call
  // in the definition of optimal is true.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call
  // is Const or Var, which are always optimal.

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>

    var o2 := optimize(e2);

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call
  // in the match statement for Add returns true.
  // Inductive case: if e is an addition, then optimize(e) simplifies the addition.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call
  // in the match statement for Add returns true.

  // Inductive case: if e is an addition, then optimize(e) is either

   |
33 |   // Inductive case: if e is an addition, then optimize(e) is either
   |                                                                     ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call
  // in the match statement for Add returns true.

  // Inductive case: if e is an addition, then optimize(e) simplifies the addition

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call
  // in the match statement for Add returns true.

  // Inductive case: if e is an addition, then optimize(e) simplifies the addition
  // by recursively optimizing its arguments, and the inductive hypothesis
  // applies to these optimized arguments.

   |
35 |   // applies to these optimized arguments.
   |                                           ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call
  // in the match statement for Add returns true.

  // Inductive case: if e is an addition, then optimize(e) simplifies the addition
  // by recursively optimizing its arguments, and the inductive hypothesis
  // implies that the optimized sub-expressions are optimal.

   |
35 |   // implies that the optimized sub-expressions are optimal.
   |                                                             ^

  | Var(name: string)

  | Var(name: string)

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call

  // by recursively optimizing its arguments, and the inductive hypothesis

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call
  // in the match statement for Add returns true.

  // Inductive case: if e is an addition, then optimize(e) simplifies the addition
  // by recursively optimizing its arguments, and the inductive hypothesis
  // guarantees that the optimized arguments are optimal.
}
```

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call

  // Inductive case: if e is an addition, then optimize(e) simplifies the addition
  // by recursively optimizing its arguments, and the inductive hypothesis
  // guarantees that the optimized arguments are optimal.

  | Var(name: string)

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

  case _ => true

    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2

    else Add(o1, o2)

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then optimize(e) is just e, and
  // it is vacuously optimal because the base case of the recursive call
  // in the match statement for Add returns true.

  // Inductive case: if e is an addition, then optimize(e) simplifies the addition
  // by recursively optimizing its arguments, and the inductive hypothesis
  // guarantees that the optimized arguments are optimal.
}
```

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  reads e
  decreases e

   |

   |         ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1

   |
18 |     else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
   |                                   ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

{

  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is a constant or variable, it's always optimal

   |
26 |   // Base case: if e is a constant or variable, it's always optimal
   |                                                                    ^

ex.dfy(26,67): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

None

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case
  if e == Const(0) || e == Var(0)
  {
    // nothing to optimize
  }
  else if e == Add(Const(0), e2)

   |
31 |   else if e == Add(Const(0), e2)
   |                                 ^

  case _ => true

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case
  if e == Const(0) || e == Var(0)
  {
    // nothing to optimize
  }
  else
  {

case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case
  if e == Const(0) || e == Var(0)
  {
    // nothing to optimize
  }
  else
  {
    // Inductive case
    // Recursive call on sub-expressions
    if e == Add(e1, e2)
    {
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }

   |
39 |     }
   |      ^

ex.dfy(39,5): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  if e == Const(0) || e == Var(0) then

   |
28 |   if e == Const(0) || e == Var(0) then
   |                                   ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

{

  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);

    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    else Add(o1, o2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // In this case, we recursively call the lemma on the sub-expressions of e

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.

### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // We know that optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2)) for some e1, e2

   |
31 |   // We know that optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2)) for some e1, e2
   |                                                                       ^

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // In this case, optimize(e) is either an addition or a non-constant expression

   |
31 |   // In this case, optimize(e) is either an addition or a non-constant expression
   |                                                                                  ^

ex.dfy(31,81): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

{

  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  // optimize(e) = optimize(Add(e1, e2)) = Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

   |
32 |   // optimize(e) = optimize(Add(e1, e2)) = Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
   |                                                                           ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e

   |
33 |   // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
   |                                                     ^

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we know that

   |
34 |   // By the induction hypothesis, we know that
   |                                               ^

ex.dfy(34,46): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE

```dafny

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

{

  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds

  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable

### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants
  // Therefore, optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

   |
36 |   // Therefore, optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
   |                                                                         ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants
  // So, optimal(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))) holds

   |
36 |   // So, optimal(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))) holds
   |                                                        ^

ex.dfy(36,55): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
TEXT

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants
  // So, optimal(Add(o1, o2)) holds where o1 == optimize(e1) and o2 == optimize(e2)

   |
36 |   // So, optimal(Add(o1, o2)) holds where o1 == optimize(e1) and o2 == optimize(e2)
   |                                                                                    ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

{

  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds

  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))

  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants
  // Thus, optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

   |
36 |   // Thus, optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
   |                                                                    ^

```dafny

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

{

  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds

  // By the definition of optimize, we have

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

{

  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2

    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds

  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))

  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants

  // So, optimal(optimize(e)) holds

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0.   case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants
  // Thus, optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  // And so, optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) holds
}

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants
  // Thus, optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  // And so, optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) holds
}
```

SCORE
1.0

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants
  // Thus, optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  // And so, optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) holds
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants

  // And so, optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) holds

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants
  // Thus, optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  // And so, optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) holds
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants
  // Thus, optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  // And so, optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) holds
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(n: nat) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e
  // Base case: e is a constant or a variable
  // In this case, optimize(e) == e and so optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  
  // Inductive case: e is an addition
  // By the definition of optimize, we have
  //   optimize(e) == optimize(Add(e1, e2))
  // We know that e1 and e2 are sub-expressions of e
  // By the induction hypothesis, we have optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
  // We also know that e1 and e2 are not both constants
  // Thus, optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  // And so, optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) holds
}
```

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
  reads e
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e

   |

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
  reads e
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)

   |

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
  reads e
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if e1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if e2 == Const(0) then o1

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  reads e
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if e1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if e2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

   |                     ^

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  reads e
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>

    var o2 := optimize(e2);

    else if e2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
  requires true

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

   |

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Add
  if e == Add(Const(0), _) {
  } else if e == Add(_, Const(0)) {
  } else if e == Add(_, _) {
    var e1 := e.e1;
    var e2 := e.e2;

   |
