### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Add
  if e == Add(Const(0), _) {
  } else if e == Add(_, Const(0)) {
  } else if e == Add(_, _) {
    var e1 := e.e1;
    var e2 := e.e2;
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);

   |
31 |     OptimizerOptimal(e1);
   |                          ^

ex.dfy(31,25): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

TEXT

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Add
  if e == Add(Const(0), _) {
  } else if e == Add(_, Const(0)) {
  } else if e == Add(_, _) {
    var e1 := e.e1;
    var e2 := e.e2;
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Add

    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Add
  if e == Add(Const(0), _) {
  } else if e == Add(_, Const(0)) {
  } else if e == Add(_, _) {
    var e1 := e.e1;
    var e2 := e.e2;
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  }
  // Base cases for other constructors
  else if e == Const(_) {
  } else if e == Var(_) {

   |
36 |   } else if e == Var(_) {
   |                          ^

ex.dfy(36,25): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on e
  switch e {

   |

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on e
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_) then

   |
26 |   if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_) then
   |                                   ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false

  case _ => e

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is a constant or variable, it's already optimal
  if e is Const || e is Var {

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is a constant or variable, it's already optimal
  if e == Const(?val) || e == Var(?name) {

   |
26 |   if e == Const(?val) || e == Var(?name) {
   |                                           ^

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is a constant or variable, it's already optimal
  if e is Const || e is Var {
  } else {
    // Inductive case: e is an addition
    // Recursively call the lemma on the operands of the addition

   |
29 |     // Recursively call the lemma on the operands of the addition
   |                                                                  ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is a constant or variable, it's already optimal
  if e is Const || e is Var {
  } else {
    // Inductive case: e is an addition
    assert e is Add
    var e1 := e.e1

   |
29 |     assert e is Add
   |                 ^^^

ex.dfy(29,16): Error: expected either 'by' or a semicolon following the assert expression
   |
30 |     var e1 := e.e1
   |                   ^

ex.dfy(30,18): Error: semicolon expected
2 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None

  | Var(name: string)

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)

  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is a constant or variable, it's already optimal
  if e is Const || e is Var {
  } else {
    // Inductive case: e is an addition
    assert e is Add
    var e1 := e.e1
    var e2 := e.e2

   |
29 |     assert e is Add
   |                 ^^^

   |
31 |     var e2 := e.e2
   |     ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt

   |

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    match (e1_opt, e2_opt)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: if e is not an addition, then the optimization doesn't change its optimality

   |
26 |   // Base case: if e is not an addition, then the optimization doesn't change its optimality
   |                                                                                             ^

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
  }

   |
29 |   }
   |    ^

### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
    // Since the expression is a constant or variable, it is already optimal
  }
  else
  {
    // Inductive case

   |
33 |     // Inductive case
   |                      ^

    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_)
  {
    // Since the expression is a constant or variable, it is already optimal
  }
  else
  {
    // Inductive case
    // Assume that the lemma is true for the sub-expressions of e
    // Then we prove it for the optimized expression
    assert e == Add(_, _);

   |
36 |     assert e == Add(_, _);
   |                           ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt

  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  {
    // Since the expression is a constant or variable, it is already optimal
  }
  else
  {
    // Inductive case
    // Assume that the lemma is true for the sub-expressions of e
    // Then we prove it for the optimized expression

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e.
  // Base cases: Const, Var

   |
27 |   // Base cases: Const, Var
   |                            ^

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  // Base cases: Const, Var
  // Inductive case: Add

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e.
  // Base cases: Const, Var
  // Inductive case: Add
  //   - Apply the lemma recursively on e1 and e2

29 |   //   - Apply the lemma recursively on e1 and e2

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e.
  // Base cases: Const, Var
  // Inductive case: Add
  //   Case analysis on e1_opt and e2_opt.

   |
29 |   //   Case analysis on e1_opt and e2_opt.
   |                                           ^

ex.dfy(29,42): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['  //   If e1_opt == Const(0), then optimal(e2_opt) by induction hypothesis.\n', '  //   - Recursive call for each sub-expression.\n', '  //   Case 1: e1 is Const(0)\n', '  //   - Apply the lemma recursively on e1 and e2\n', '  //   Case analysis on e1_opt and e2_opt.\n']
TEXT

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  // Base cases: Const, Var

CHOSEN SOLUTION
### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by induction on the structure of e.
  // Base cases: Const, Var
  // Inductive case: Add
  //   Case 1: e1 is Const(0)
  //   Case 2: e2 is Const(0)
  //   Case 3: Both e1 and e2 are not Const(0)
}
```

number of gen nodes: 12 (including leaves: 1)
number of back nodes: 11 (including leaves: 11)

expansion count: 12 (including failed: 1)

calls to generate 47

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
  reads e
  decreases e

   |
15 |   reads e
   |         ^

1 resolution/type errors detected in ex.dfy

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);

match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base case: If e is not an addition, then it stays the same after optimization.

   |
29 |   // Base case: If e is not an addition, then it stays the same after optimization.
   |                                                                                    ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } else

   |
32 |   } else
   |         ^

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } 
  else if e == Add(Const(0), Var("")) {

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } 
  // Inductive cases
  else if e == Add(e1, e2) {
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);

   |
35 |     var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
   |                                ^

  case _ => true

    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt

    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } 
  // Inductive cases
  else if e == Add(e1, e2) {
    // Recursive calls
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    // No additions by 0
    assert e1 != Const(0);
    assert e2 != Const(0);
  }

   |
41 |   }
   |    ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } 
  // Inductive cases
  else if e == Add(e1, e2) {
    // Recursive calls
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    // No additions by 0
    assert e1 != Const(0);
    assert e2 != Const(0);
  } else {

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } 
  // Inductive cases
  else if e == Add(e1, e2) {
    // Recursive calls
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    // No additions by 0
    assert e1 != Const(0);
    assert e2 != Const(0);
  }
  // Other cases
  else {
    assert forall e1, e2 :: e == Add(e1, e2) ? optimal(optimize(e)) : true;

   |
44 |     assert forall e1, e2 :: e == Add(e1, e2) ? optimal(optimize(e)) : true;
   |                                            ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } 
  // Inductive cases
  else if e == Add(e1, e2) {
    // Recursive calls
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    // No additions by 0
    assert e1 != Const(0);
    assert e2 != Const(0);
  }
  // Other cases
  else {
    // Recursive calls
    OptimizerOptimal(e);

   |
45 |     OptimizerOptimal(e);
   |                         ^

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e

   |
29 |   // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
   |                                                     ^

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt

  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal

   |

   |                                      ^

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case _ => true

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. Add with 0 on the left is not optimal

   |
32 |   // 2. Add with 0 on the left is not optimal
   |                                              ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

  | Var(name: string)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. If optimization removes Add(0, e) or Add(e, 0), then it's optimal

   |
32 |   // 2. If optimization removes Add(0, e) or Add(e, 0), then it's optimal
   |                                                                          ^

  | Var(name: string)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. If e is Add(e1, e2) and e1_opt or e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) is the same as optimal(e2_opt or e1_opt)

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. If e is Add(e1, e2) and e1_opt or e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // Inductive step:

   |
34 |   // Inductive step:
   |                     ^

ex.dfy(34,20): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['  // Inductive case:\n', '  // Inductive step:\n', '  // Inductive step:\n', '  // Inductive case:\n', '  // Inductive case:\n']
TEXT

  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. If e is Add(e1, e2) and e1_opt or e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // Inductive step:
  // 3. If e is Add(e1, e2) and neither e1_opt nor e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // This is because the recursive call OptimizerOptimal(e1) and OptimizerOptimal(e2)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. If e is Add(e1, e2) and e1_opt or e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // Inductive step:
  // 3. If e is Add(e1, e2) and neither e1_opt nor e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // The proof is by pattern matching on e and then calling OptimizerOptimal recursively on the sub-expressions.

   |
37 |   // The proof is by pattern matching on e and then calling OptimizerOptimal recursively on the sub-expressions.
   |                                                                                                                 ^

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. If e is Add(e1, e2) and e1_opt or e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // Inductive step:
  // 3. If e is Add(e1, e2) and neither e1_opt nor e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // This is because the recursive call OptimizerOptimal(e1) and OptimizerOptimal(e2)
  // establishes the inductive hypothesis

   |                                          ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. If e is Add(e1, e2) and e1_opt or e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // Inductive step:
  // 3. If e is Add(e1, e2) and neither e1_opt nor e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // This is because the recursive call OptimizerOptimal(e1) and OptimizerOptimal(e2)
  // will ensure that e1_opt and e2_opt are optimal, and so is their addition.

   |
38 |   // will ensure that e1_opt and e2_opt are optimal, and so is their addition.
   |                                                                               ^

ex.dfy(38,78): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
TEXT

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. If e is Add(e1, e2) and e1_opt or e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // Inductive step:
  // 3. If e is Add(e1, e2) and neither e1_opt nor e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // This is because the recursive call OptimizerOptimal(e1) and OptimizerOptimal(e2)
  // establish that e1_opt and e2_opt are both optimal, so Add(e1_opt, e2_opt) is optimal.

   |
38 |   // establish that e1_opt and e2_opt are both optimal, so Add(e1_opt, e2_opt) is optimal.
   |                                                                                           ^

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. If e is Add(e1, e2) and e1_opt or e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // Inductive step:
  // 3. If e is Add(e1, e2) and neither e1_opt nor e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // This is because the recursive call OptimizerOptimal(e1) and OptimizerOptimal(e2)
  // establishes the inductive hypothesis.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var e1_opt := optimize(e1);
    var e2_opt := optimize(e2);
    if e1_opt == Const(0) then e2_opt
    else if e2_opt == Const(0) then e1_opt
    else Add(e1_opt, e2_opt)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Proof by structural induction on the shape of e
  // Base cases:
  // 1. Const, Var are always optimal
  // 2. If e is Add(e1, e2) and e1_opt or e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // Inductive step:
  // 3. If e is Add(e1, e2) and neither e1_opt nor e2_opt is Const(0), then
  //    optimal(optimize(e)) holds
  // This is because the recursive call OptimizerOptimal(e1) and OptimizerOptimal(e2)
  // establishes the inductive hypothesis
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  reads e
  modifies nothing
  decreases e

   |   ^

  case _ => true

  case _ => true

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)

   |
19 |     else Add(o1, o2)
   |                     ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>

    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Const and Var
  if e == Const(0) || e == Var("") {

   |
27 |   if e == Const(0) || e == Var("") {
   |                                     ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Const and Var
  if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_) {

   |
27 |   if e == Const(_) || e == Var(_) {
   |                                    ^

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Const and Var
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } else
  // Recursive cases
  match e

   |
31 |   match e
   |   ^

31 |   match e
   |          ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Const and Var
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } else
  // Recursive cases
  if e == Add(Const(0), _) {

datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    var o1 := optimize(e1);

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Const and Var
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } else
  // Recursive cases
  if e == Add(e1, e2) {
    // Call lemma recursively
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  }
}

   |
31 |   if e == Add(e1, e2) {
   |               ^^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  // Base cases for Const and Var
  if e == Const(0) {
  } else if e == Var("") {
  } else
  // Recursive cases
  if e == Add(e1, e2) {
    // Call lemma recursively
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  }
  // Other cases are not necessary because they are covered by the base cases

   |
36 |   // Other cases are not necessary because they are covered by the base cases
   |                                                                              ^

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

  case _ => true

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    var o1 := optimize(e1);
    var o2 := optimize(e2);
    if o1 == Const(0) then o2
    else if o2 == Const(0) then o1
    else Add(o1, o2)
  case _ => e
}
